questions.question: What is the population covered by Municipal Boards?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) 10,000-2,00,000 Explanation: Municipal board operates in urban areas and covers a population of 10,000-2,00,000. Municipal Board: Aspect Details Head Chairman or President, elected by members of the Municipal Board. Term Typically 3 to 5 years. Functions Construction and maintenance of roads, bridges, and public infrastructure. Sanitation and drainage systems. Street lighting. Water supply. Maintenance of hospitals and dispensaries. Education. Civil registration (births and deaths). Administration Executive Agency: This includes the Commissioner, Secretary, Engineer, and Health Officer. Councillors: Elected from different wards of the city. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 1006

questions.question: The logo shown above represents a health scheme launched by the Government of India. What is the primary objective of this program?

options.A: To provide comprehensive outbreak response essential drugs and diagnostic services.
options.B: To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged
options.C: To reduce morbidity due to vaccine-preventable diseases in children
options.D: To promote accessible, affordable, and quality healthcare to the rural population

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) To offer health insurance coverage to the economically disadvantaged the Government of India designed to provide health insurance coverage to economically disadvantaged families. Ayushman Bharat - Pradhan Mantri Jan Arogya Yojana (PMJAY): An initiative launched in 2018 by Govt. of India to achieve UHC Provides all the elements, including NCDS, in primary care. Benefits: Coverage : up to INR 5 lakh per family per year for secondary and tertiary care hospitalization. There is no restriction on the number of family members. Cashless access across the country All pre-existing conditions covered Covers the cost of treatment, up to 3 days of pre-hospitalization and 15 days of post-hospitalization follow-up care. Beneficiaries:

questions.question: A 30-year-old laborer struggles to access basic healthcare services due to high costs and limited availability. The logo shown below represents an initiative that aims to address issues like the one faced by this patient. Which healthcare concept does this logo represent?

options.A: National Program for Prevention and Control of cancer and diabetes

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Universal Health Coverage Explanation: The logo represents Universal Health Coverage (UHC) ensuring that all individuals receive health services without suffering financial hardship. Universal Health Coverage: 12th December: International Universal Health Coverage Day given by the United States. Includes a full range of essential health services , from health promotion to prevention, treatment, rehabilitation, and palliative care. Includes non-communicable diseases (NCDS) and AYUSH. Includes financial protection: Insurance coverage. Global program with the key target of the UN Sustainable Development. Goals, aiming to achieve UHC by 2030. Aims : Equity in access (Everywhere, everyone who needs services should get them). Good quality and affordable health service. Protection against financial risk (without having to bear financial hardship). The Accessible India Campaign (Sugamya Bharat Abhiyan) was launched to create a barrier-free and favorable environment for universal accessibility to people with disabilities. The Integrated Disease Surveillance Project (IDSP) is designed to improve disease surveillance and response to outbreaks. The National Programme for Prevention and Control of Non-Communicable Diseases (NPCDCS) aims to tackle non-communicable diseases (NCDs) through prevention, early diagnosis, and management.

questions.question: Which primary healthcare principle is represented by the displayed image to ensure appropriate usability and quality?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) Appropriate Technology Explanation: The usage of Vaccine Vial Monitors (VVMs) to ensure vaccine usability and quality falls under the pillar of appropriate technology in primary healthcare. Four Pillars of Primary Health Care: Equitable distribution (Option D): Equitable distribution of health services irrespective of their socio-economic status. Intersectoral coordination (Option C): Involves collaboration from other sectors like agriculture, education, etc. Maintains good health. Appropriate technology (Option A): Use of technology that is accessible, affordable, and suitable for the community Eg: ORS VVM (Vaccine Vial Monitor): Heat sensitive label Shakir tape: Malnutrition grading Kangaroo mother care: Preterm care Community participation (Option B): Ensure the participation of the community in planning, implementing and maintaining. For the promotion and maintenance of their health. Eg: ASHA workers are residents of the same community. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pg: 693-694

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding elements of primary healthcare are true: 1. It includes education concerning health problems and methods of preventing them. 2. It involves the promotion of food supply and appropriate nutrition. 3. It provides essential and non-essential drugs. 4. It consists of individuals who have a common health goal based on community requirements. 5. It emphasizes maternal and child health care, including family planning.
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A) 1,2, and 5 Explanation: Elements or Components of Primary Health Care according to ‘Declaration of Alma Ata’in Kazakhistan: Mnemonic: ELEMENTS E ssential medicines (especially paracetamol) (Statement 3) L ocally endemic diseases -Prevention and Control Health E ducation (Statement 1) M aternal, child health and family planning (Statement 5) E PI (Expanded Immunization Programme) now changed to UIP (Universal Immunization Programme) N utrition and food supply (Statement 2) T reatment of common ailments S afe water supply and sanitation Note: A health team is defined as a group of people sharing a common health goal and objectives, determined by community needs and towards the achievement of which each member contributes with her or his competence and respects the functions of the other. (Statement 4) Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pg 36-37

questions.question: Which of the following does not come under the 4 A's of primary healthcare?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: C) Accountability Explanation: Accountability, which relates to the responsibility of healthcare providers to deliver quality care, is not listed among the 4 A's of primary healthcare. Health for All: Proposed in 1977 by the World Health Assembly. Attainment of the level of health by all individuals enabling them to lead socially and economically productive lives. The 4 A's of primary healthcare are: Accessibility: Healthcare services are available and reachable by all. Affordability: Healthcare services are economically viable for all Acceptability: Healthcare services are culturally and socially appropriate Availability: Appropriate ratio between the population of an administrative unit and the health facility Principles of primary health care: Appropriate technology Community participation Equitable distribution Inter-sectoral coordination Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pg 36

questions.question: What should be the minimum number of members in the Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: D) 15 Explanation: Village Health Sanitation and Nutrition Committee-VHSNC: Aspect Details Formation Formed at the revenue village level Composition There are at least 15 members , including elected Panchayat members (committee leaders), health workers, community members/beneficiaries, and representatives from vulnerable sections and hamlets. Member Secretary ASHA (also the convener of VHSNC). Roles and Responsibilities Create awareness and conduct surveys about nutritional issues and deficiencies. Identify local nutritious foods and include them in the Village Health Plan. Monitor Village Health and Nutrition Day. Facilitate referral to Nutritional Rehabilitation Centre (NRC). Supervise Anganwadi Centre (AWC). Act as grievances redressal forum on health and nutrition. Relationship with Gram Panchayat Acts as a sub-committee under the overall supervision of Gram Panchayat. Reference: https://www.nhm.gov.in/index1.php?lang=1&level=1&sublinkid=149&lid=225 Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 516

questions.question: What is the role of Rogi Kalyan Samiti?

options.D: Support the functioning of health facilities

questions.explanation: Correct answer : D) Support the functioning of health facilities Explanation: Rogi Kalyan Samiti: Aspect Details Synonyms Patient Welfare Committee Hospital Management Society Purpose Manage hospital affairs, ensure patient welfare, and improve facilities in hospitals. Structure Registered society with community members as trustees. Financial Assistance Provided through untied funds for activities related to patient welfare. Responsibilities Upkeep of hospital facilities. Ensuring the provision of better facilities to patients. Financial management and accountability. Community engagement and participation. Location It is found in almost all DHs, SDHs, CHCs, and PHCs across India. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 516

questions.question: Which committee established the Panchayati Raj Institution?
questions.explanation: Correct answer: A)Balwant Rai Mehta Committee. Explanation: The Panchayati Raj Institution was established by the Balwant Rai Mehta Committee. Panchayati Raj: 3-tier structure of rural self-government. Links village to district. Panchayati Raj Institutions: Panchayat- at the village level. Panchayat samiti- at block level. Zilla parishad - at the district level. Level Institution Description and Functions Village Gram Sabha Assembly of all adults in the village; discusses local issues; elects members of Gram Panchayat. Gram Panchayat The executive body of Gram Sabha; plans and executes local development activities, led by a President (Sarpanch). Nyaya Panchayat Deals with local disputes and minor offences; provides justice at the village level. Block Panchayat Samiti Consists of Sarpanchas (heads) of village Panchayats, MLAs, MPs, and others; implements community development. Block Development Officer (BDO) Secretary of Panchayat Samiti; provides technical guidance for development projects. District Zilla Parishad Represents Panchayat Samitis, MLAs, MPs, and others; supervises and coordinates development activities at the district level. District Administration Includes administrative officers (e.g., District Collector) responsible for overall governance. Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 1006-1007 IAPSM 2nd edition, page 862

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT an ASHA role?

options.A: Providing counseling on birth preparedness and safe delivery
options.B: Administering vaccines to infants and children
options.C: Mobilizing the community for health awareness programs
options.D: Providing directly observed treatment short-course (DOTS) for tuberculosis

questions.explanation: CORRECT ANSWER: B) Administering vaccines to infants and children Explanation: Roles of ASHA: Educating on health determinants Counseling women on birth preparedness, safe delivery, breastfeeding, immunization, contraception, and prevention of infection Mobilizing the community to access health services Working with village health and sanitation committees Escorting pregnant women and children to health facilities Providing primary medical care for minor ailments and first aid Providing DOTS Acting as a depot holder for essential provisions and drug kits Reporting births, deaths, and health issues to health centres Promoting the construction of household toilets Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Page 700-701

questions.question: All of the following are true about a primary health centre (PHC) except?

options.A: The presence of an AYUSH officer is not essential
options.C: At least 2 staff nurses per PHC should be present
options.D: The recommended bed count is at least 6 per PHC

questions.explanation: Correct answer: B) Type A PHC: delivery load <15 Explanation: Type A PHC: delivery load < 20 Standards per PHC: Staffing count Type A: 13-18 Type B: 14-21 Staffing division Essential: 1 medical officer, 2 nurses, 1 pharmacist, 1 health worker male & 1 health worker female, 1 lab technician (Option C) Desirable: 1 AYUSH officer (Option A) Categorization Type A: <20 deliveries (Option B) Type B: >20 deliveries Bed count Six (Option D) Services 24*7 emergency services Minimum 6 hours of outpatient service Antenatal, perinatal (normal delivery & cesarean section) and postnatal services MTP & contraception Neonatal & infant care Pediatric care: pneumonia, diarrhea, SAM Communicable & non-communicable diseases services Reference: Park’s Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th Edition, Pages 706-712
